lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Mal.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Mal.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
// Update the title above to match the actual product name
// Describe the action and its outcome.
// A description of the expected outcome goes here
* Acts as the main entry point for the Mal task management application.
* This class initializes the user interface, storage system, and task list,
* and manages the primary execution loop.
/** The default file path used for data persistence. */
* Initializes the application by setting up the UI and storage.
* Attempts to load existing tasks from the specified file path;
* if loading fails, a new empty task list is initialized.
* @param PATH The file path where task data is stored and retrieved.
* Starts the main command loop of the application.
* Continuously reads user input, deciphers commands using the Parser,
* and updates the TaskList and Storage accordingly until the user exits.
* Serves as the main entry point to start the Mal application.
* @throws MalException If an error occurs during program initialization.
public static void main(String[] args) throws MalException {
* Manages the in-memory list of tasks.
* Provides methods to add, delete, mark, and display tasks within the collection.
* Initializes a TaskList with an existing collection of tasks.
* @param list An ArrayList of Task objects.
* Adds a task to the list.
* @param t The task to be added.
* Prints all tasks currently in the list to the console.
* If the list is empty, displays a prompt to add tasks.
System.out.println(LINE + "\nHere's the master plan, i guess");
System.out.println("There is nothing to show, genius. Add some tasks!");
* Marks a specific task as completed based on its index.
* If the task is already marked, provides feedback to the user.
* @param idx The 0-based index of the task in the list.
System.out.println("Stop harping on the same old rotten apple!");
* Reopens a specific task by marking it as not completed.
* @param idx The 0-based index of the task in the list.
System.out.println("you never got to this...." + LINE);
System.out.println("Oh boohoo, we're reopening old wounds\n" + list.get(idx).toString()
* Removes a task from the list based on its index.
* Displays a confirmation message reflecting the task's completion status.
* @param idx The 0-based index of the task to be removed.
+ "\nLet's call that a strategic decision, hm?\n"
* Displays a summary message after a task has been successfully added.
* Includes the current task count for the user.
* Returns the underlying ArrayList containing the tasks.
* Primarily used for data persistence and storage.
* @return The internal ArrayList of Task objects.
* finds and returns a filtered list of tasks with the keyword
* @param name This is the keyword to search by
System.out.println("Nothing found. My archives are incomplete.");
* Deciphers user input and executes the corresponding commands.
* This class serves as the bridge between raw user strings and the application logic.
* Initializes a Parser with the raw user input.
* Splits the input into a command word and subsequent details.
* @param input The full line of text entered by the user.
* Extracts and returns the primary command word from the input.
* Updates the internal state to reflect if the input consists of only one word.
* @return The first word of the user input in string format.
* Executes the logic associated with the identified command.
* This method handles task creation, deletion, marking, and listing by
* @param taskList The TaskList object where tasks are managed.
* @return True if the command was recognized and executed, false otherwise.
Ui.showError("Ah yes, Mal.task number 'that one'. A classic. Tragically fictional");
Ui.showError("Ah yes, Mal.task number 'that one'. A classic. Tragically fictional\n");
Ui.showError("You can't delete what was never added");
// Checkstyle requires a default case even if it does nothing
* deals with the storage of Tasks as a String and to
* initialises a storage with a filePath
* @param filePath String This is the path to the file to store tasks
* Loads tasks from the storage file and reconstructs them into a list.
* If the file does not exist or is empty, an empty list is returned.
* Malformed or empty lines within the file are skipped.
* @return A list of tasks reconstructed from the storage file.
System.out.println("Seems like you're starting from scratch!");
System.out.println("You gotta give me something to work off of, "
+ "I cannot show you a file that doesn't exist!");
* Saves a list of Task as stored strings
* @param list This is the list of tasks to be saved
System.out.println("slow your roll! Give me time to communicate the plan");
* Represents a task that needs to be completed by a specific deadline.
* Initializes a new DeadlineTask with a name and a deadline.
* @param deadline The time or date by which the task must be completed.
* Initializes a new DeadlineTask with a name, completion status, and deadline.
* Primarily used for loading tasks from storage.
* @param isDone The completion status of the task.
* @param deadline The time or date by which the task must be completed.
public DeadlineTask(String name, boolean isDone, String deadline) {
* Parses user input to create a DeadlineTask.
* Attempts to format the deadline if provided in ISO date format.
* @param s The raw command string containing task details and the deadline delimiter.
System.out.println("Details. I need details. Magic has limits.");
* Reconstructs a DeadlineTask from a stored data string.
* @param n The pipe-delimited string from the storage file.
* @return A DeadlineTask with the saved state and deadline.
* Returns a formatted string for saving the deadline task to a file.
* @return A string in the format D|status|name|deadline.
* Returns a string representation of the deadline task for display.
* @return Formatted string with [D] prefix and the deadline.
* Initializes a new EventTask with a name, start time, and end time.
* @param start The start time or date of the event.
* @param end The end time or date of the event.
public EventTask(String name, String start, String end) {
* Initializes a new EventTask with a name, completion status, start time, and end time.
* Primarily used for loading tasks from storage.
* @param isDone The completion status of the task.
* @param start The start time or date of the event.
* @param end The end time or date of the event.
public EventTask(String name, boolean isDone, String start, String end) {
* Parses user input to create an EventTask.
* Handles date parsing if the input matches ISO format (YYYY-MM-DD).
* @param s The raw command string containing task details and time delimiters.
System.out.println("Right, we have something to do....but we dom't know what and when?");
System.out.println("I have magic, not mind reading abilities. I need details");
Task t = new EventTask(details[0], start, end);
* Reconstructs an EventTask from a stored data string.
* @param n The pipe-delimited string from the storage file.
* @return An EventTask with the saved state and time details.
return new EventTask(arr[1], true, arr[2], arr[3]);
return new EventTask(arr[1], false, arr[2], arr[3]);
* Returns a formatted string for saving the event to a file.
* @return A string in the format E|status|name|start|end.
* Returns a string representation of the event for display.
* @return Formatted string with [E] prefix and time range.
* Represents a generic task that can be tracked.
* This class serves as a base for specific task types like Todo, Deadline, and Event.
* Initializes a new Task with the given name.
* By default, the task is marked as not done.
* @param name The description of the task.
* Initializes a new Task with a given name and completion status.
* Used primarily when loading tasks from storage.
* @param name The description of the task.
* @param isDone The completion status of the task.
* Returns the description of the task.
* Checks if the task has been marked as completed.
* @return True if the task is done, false otherwise.
* Returns a formatted string representation of the task for file storage.
* @return A string containing task details formatted for storage.
* Marks the task as not completed.
* Returns a string representation of the task, including its status icon.
* @return A formatted string showing task status and description.
* Deals with all tasks of the 'todo' type
* Initializes a new TodoTask with the specified name
* constructor using name and to set 'marked' state

* Reconstructs a TodoTask from a stored data string.

* Converts a Task to a String in the format to be stored

* The Ui class deals with interactions with the user,

System.out.println(LINE + "
Hello I'm Mal
You summoned me?
" + LINE);
* Prints out the message after a task a=has been added
* @param t This is that task that has been added
* @param size This is the size of the list
public void showAdded(Task t, int size) {

System.out.println(LINE + "
Added:
" + t + "
Now you have " + size + " tasks for world domination
" + LINE);
System.out.println(LINE + "\nFinally. I thought you'd never stop talking. Stay rotten.\n" + LINE);
